IRAQ.^ TURKISH PRO-POSALS FORA DIRECTSETTLEMENT of the TURCO-IRAQFRONTIERQUESTION.(previous reference:Cabinet 5(25), Con-elusion 7.)2. The Oabinet had before them a Memorandum by the secretary of State for Foreign Affairs reporting thaton various oooasions during and since the protraotednegotiations over the question of Mosul the Turks had proposed that His Majesty^ Government should hand thevilayet over to them in return for eoonomio and commercial advantages; and that, in spite of thefact that such overtures had been repeatedly refusedand that as recently as January last Mr austen chamberlain had Informed the Turkish Minister thatHis Majesty's Government could not consent to bargainaway the rights of Iraq, of which they were trustees,in exchange for economic advantages to Britishsubjects, and that it would be useless for the TurkishGovernment to submit any proposals based on such asuggestion, the Turkish Government had now made formalproposals for an agreement on this basis (Paper CP. -194 (25)).The Cabinet agreed (a) To approve the proposal of the Secretaryof State for Foreign Affairs that heshould return a firm but polite refusal to the offer communicated by the turkish minister, and should intimate that wemust await the result of the inquiryof the League of Nations Commission:(b) That the Seoretary of State for ForeignAffairs, subjeot to (a), should bear inmind the desirability j from the point ofview of our polioy in India* of keepingon as good terms as possible with the Turks. RUSSIA.BritishPolicytowards.(previous reference:Cabinet 66(24)s Con-clusion 14.)3. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairscalled the attention of his colleagues to his interview with M. Rakoyski on April 1, 1925 (despatch No. 249 ofApril 1, 1925, to Mr Hodgson (Moscow) - Foreign OfficeN.1852/102/38), and expressed the hope that theattitude he had taken met with the approval of theCabinet.The President of the Board of Trade said that hehad been approached by various interests, such as theRussian bondholders and certain cotton interests, whowere contemplating entering into private negotiationswith the Russian Soviet Government'. He had told themthat the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs mustbe informed of their.negotiations, but that from thepoint of view of trade it was advantageous that private negotiations of this kind should be undertaken,provided that the negotiators clearly understood thatthey must not encourage any idea of political conces-sions by the Government.The Cabinet approved the line taken bythe Secretary of State for Foreign affairs in his interview with M. Rakovski, andthe line taken by the President of theBoard of Trade, as summarised above. 4. In addition to the Memoranda which were beforethem when the question of the Benguella Railway and a trade Facilities Guarantee was last considered (Papers0.P.-137 (25) and CP.-140 (25)), the Oabinet had before them the following doouments:-The replies from the Governments ofNorthern and Southern Rhodesia to atelegram addressed to them by the secretary of State for the Colonies(Paper CP.-192 (25));A Note by the Secretary to the Cabinet,circulating extracts (communicated bythe Attorney-General) from the Report,dated March 16, 1925, of TanganyikaConcessions, Limited, relative to ,the question of immediate completionIn any event of the Benguella Railway(Paper CP.-169 (25)).The Cabinet agreed -That, in view of the certainty thatin any event the Benguella Railwaywould be built; on the understandingthat if a guarantee was grantedorders would be given in this countryfor railway material, that is to say,in the industry where unemployment isat its worst; and having regard tothe tenor of the telegrams from theGovernments of Northern and SouthernRhodesia; the Trade FacilitiesCommittee should he free to consideran application for a guarantee on its merits. 5. The Chancellor of the Exchequer gave the cabinet a short verbal account of the present position of had discussions .with the French Government on the subjectof Inter-Allied Debts.M. Fleuriau, the French Ambassador, on returning from his recent visit to Paris, had stated that theFrench Government were willing to discuss the questionof Inter-Allied Debts on the basis of the Chancellorof the Exchequer's Note (Paper CP.-58 (25)), and thatM. Clement el wished to come over to discuss the matter with the Chancellor of the Exchequer, but that at the - ''moment he was unable to make the visit, In the meantimeM. Clementel had asked M. Fleuriau to arrange for french experts to discuss the question in a preliminary-way with representatives of the Treasury. discussions had taken place at the Treasury during the last week,and the. French experts had outlined certain proposalswhich they had eventually set out in an informal -aide-memoire. -While these proposals constituted a consider-able advance on the position taken up by the FrenchGovernment a year or two ago, they were far from beingacceptable to the British Government, and the Treasuryexperts had made this quite clear. On leaving, theFrench experts had intimated that the negotiationsmust not be regarded as broken off.At the moment Mr Churchill made it clear thathe was asking for no decision, and was only informing the Cabinet of the progress made with this question.He might later ask them for a decision. UNEMPLOYME NT.The ScottishOil ShaleMines.(previous reference:Cabinet 19(25), Oon-conclusion 7.)6. The Cabinet had before them the Report of theUnemployment Committee (Paper 0. P. -184 (25) Revise)on the subject of the Scottish Oil Shale Mines.While the trend of the discussion was to theeffect that it would be impossible to justify, on naval or strategic grounds, the grant of a subsidy,whether veiled in the form of an Admiralty contractor otherwise, to the Scottish oil shale industrywithout creating a, precedent which it might bedifficult to resist in the case of other failing .industries, it was felt that the whole questionrequired further consideration. 'The Cabinet agreed (a) That the question should be adjourned for" further consideration:(b) That the President of the Board ofTrade should discuss the matter further. with representatives of the Anglo-Persian Oil Company with a view, ifpossible, to obtaining a postponementfor two or three months of the closing of the works, or at any rate of theleast unprofitable part thereof:(c) That the Chancellor of the Exchequerand the President of the Board ofTrade should examine the question of whether it would be possible andadvisable to give some interim and temporary support to the Scottish oilshale industry, in order to gain timefor studying the question of alternative employment for the workers. 7. The Cabinet had before them the Report of aCabinet Committee on the subject of Government policy regarding International Labour Affairs (Paper198 (25)).The Cabinet agreed - (a) That, as this long Report had only been circulated just before the Meeting, itwas impossible to discuss it on thepresent occasion:(b) That , in dealing with the WashingtonHours Convention in the Debate on the adjournment on the following day, theMinister of Labour should base himself on the last sentence of Appendix IIIto CP.-198 (25) , which is as follows:-"While His Majesty's Government donot at present see their way to overcome the difficulties whichprevent the formal ratification of the Hours Convention in itspresent form, it is their Intentionto co-operate to the fullest possible extent with the International Labour -Office in carrying out the principles laid down in Part XIII of the'Treaty(of Versailles)." waterloo bridge.(previous reference:Cabinet 10(25) , Con-conclusion 14. )8o The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum .bythe First Commissioner of Works in regard to thedecision of the London County Council to demolishWaterloo Bridge and to erect a modern bridge in its place (Paper CP. -201 (25)).The Cabinet agreed That the question of Y/aterloo Bridgefell entirely within the responsibilityof the London County Council, and thatthe public interest did not require that' the Government should intervene..in the matter.-8- 9.
